Award.AwardTitle: Photoinduced Charge Transfer at Quantum Dot-Molecule-Semiconductor Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
David Watson at the University at Buffalo (UB) is supported by an award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program to study photoinduced charge-transfer processes at quantum dot (QD)-molecule-semiconductor interfaces. The research involves basic science to tether QDs to semiconductor substrates or to each other via small molecules, and to characterize charge transfer at the resulting interfaces using time-resolved spectroscopy and photoelectrochemistry. One research initiative involves elucidating the influence of interfacial chemistry and properties on the mechanisms, dynamics, and yields of charge transfer at QD-molecule-TiO2 interfaces. Specific aims are to increase the stability and inertness of interfaces while maintaining high charge-transfer yields and promoting long-lived charge separation, to measure charge-transfer dynamics at complex interfaces, and to engineer interfacial properties to promote long-distance charge-transfer between QDs and TiO2. A second research initiative involves covalently tethering QDs to each other via carbodiimide chemistry and exploring the photoinduced charge-transfer reactivity of the resulting assemblies. Goals are to establish synthetic methods and to synthesize Type-II interfaces that promote the separation of photogenerated charges. A third research initiative involves tethering QD-molecule-QD assemblies to electron- or hole-accepting semiconductor substrates, towards the goal of promoting photoinduced vectorial charge transfer.

Semiconductor QDs have unique size-dependent electronic and optical properties, which make them intriguing harvesters of light and donors of energetic electrons and holes for solar energy conversion. QD-based solar cells and photocatalysts require (1) the controlled placement of QDs on nanostructured surfaces and (2) the existence of mechanisms through which photogenerated electrons or holes can be extracted from QDs before recombining. This research project involves basic science to establish syntheses of stable and inert QD-containing interfaces and to discover how the structure and properties of such interfaces govern the rates and efficiencies of charge-transfer reactions. The research addresses two basic challenges in materials chemistry: (1) to assemble materials interfaces precisely and (2) to establish structure-property-reactivity relationships involving charge transfer at complex interfaces. This award supports outreach programs involving collaboration between researchers at UB and students and teachers at Buffalo Public Schools. Outreach activities involve mentoring high school students and teachers in hands-on research projects. Goals are to introduce participants to the nature of scientific research, to increase teacher content knowledge, and to develop expanded mentoring networks. Research and educational initiatives are intended to benefit society by yielding new fundamental knowledge pertaining to solar energy conversion while broadening the participation of underrepresented groups and advancing discovery and understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Due to their unusual size-dependent electronic properties, semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) are intriguing for basic science and for applications in solar energy conversion, arguably the greatest challenge facing scientists. QD-based solar cells and photocatalysts require (1) the controlled placement of QDs at extended or nanostructured interfaces and (2) the existence of mechanisms through which photogenerated charge carriers (electrons and holes) can be extracted from QDs before they recombine and undesirably dissipate energy as light or heat. Therefore, fundamental challenges, with real-world implications, are to fabricate stable and inert QD-derived heterostructures and materials interfaces with precisely-controlled chemical and physical properties and to promote fast and efficient excited-state charge transfer across such interfaces. The intellectual merit of the research funded by this NSF award derived from its focus on addressing these basic and significant scientific challenges. Two key outcomes are as follows:

Elucidation of the mechanism of light-induced electron transfer from QDs to molecularly-tethered semiconductor substrates. QDs differ from bulk semiconductors in that their surfaces can play an outsized role in determining their electronic properties. Our research revealed that surface-localized electronic "trap" states can play an important role in the excited-state electron transfer reactions of QDs. Our primary goal was to determine (1) whether electrons are transferred from bulk-like band-edge states or surface-localized trap states of QDs, or both, and (2) to what extent the electron-transfer mechanism depends on the chemical and physical environment at QD-containing interfaces and the energetic distribution of trap states. These questions are of fundamental scientific interest but are also directly relevant to the use of QDs in solar energy conversion. Trapping of photogenerated charges prior to their extraction from the QDs would result in the dissipation of potential energy of the absorbed photon and a corresponding decrease of the reducing potential of the electron and/or oxidizing potential of the hole (the positive-charge carrier), both of which ultimately decrease the maximum achievable power-conversion efficiency of solar cells or photocatalysts. We discovered that, under most conditions, electrons could be extracted efficiently from photoexcited QDs within several nanoseconds (billionths of a second) after the initial absorption of light. The electron-transfer mechanism often involved the relaxation of electrons into trap states before they were removed from the QDs; however, appropriate treatment of the surfaces of QDs prevented the undesired trapping of electrons and also the deleterious removal of holes from QDs. Therefore, the research contributed to the fundamental science underpinning the use of QDs, an intriguing class of nanostructured light-harvesting material, for solar energy conversion and the production of solar fuels.

Programmable synthesis of quantum dot heterostructures for light-harvesting and charge separation. To assemble nanoparticulate building blocks into ordered materials with desirable properties and functionalities is an enduring challenge and a key objective in materials science. We aimed to address this challenge by assembling QDs into heterostructures by forming covalent bonds between the terminal functional groups (collections of atoms) of surface-attached molecules. The selectivity of covalent-bonding interactions ensured that only heterostructures of QDs, rather than undesired composites consisting of only a single type of QD, were formed. Several different classes of heterostructures, consisting of QDs with different compositions, sizes, and electronic properties, were synthesized and characterized. The absorption of visible light by a given QD within a heterostructure was typically followed, within billionths of a second, by the transfer of an electron to a different QD. This separation of photogenerated charges is a central step in mechanisms for solar-to-electrical and solar-to-chemical energy conversion.

Broader impacts: This NSF award supported a summer internship program in which high school students from the Buffalo Public School (BPS) District performed research in science and engineering under the direction of faculty and students at the University at Buffalo. This outreach initiative promoted teaching, training, and learning by engaging high school students in research. Participants developed laboratory skills, increased their content knowledge, were introduced to the methodology and excitement of scientific research, developed skills in scientific writing and communication, and became involved in expanded mentoring networks with researchers at the University at Buffalo. Outreach activities broadened the participation of underrepresented groups by focusing on students from BPS, the poorest urban school district in New York State. This NSF award also enabled the training and development of undergraduate and graduate students at the University at Buffalo. These students were trained in the methodology of research, gained hands-on skills in experimental science, acquired knowledge of fundamental concepts in inorganic, materials, and physical chemistry, and developed skills in scientific literacy and communication. Finally, as outlined above, the research project addressed significant scientific challenges - solar energy conversion and nanofabrication - with importance to society.
